Key Arguments: The proposed legislation is inappropriate and unconstitutional for the role of ACMA as the Communications Regulator.
The legislation is inconsistent with democratic principles that allow dissenting views to be expressed and discussed freely.
There are entrenched flaws in the Australian electoral process that undermine the legitimacy of the proposed legislation.
The definition of 'excluded content' in the draft legislation is problematic as it assumes certain content is not misinformation, which is not necessarily true.
Main Themes: Constitutionality and legality of the legislation
Freedom of speech and democratic principles
Criticism of the electoral process and governance
Concerns about the definition and handling of misinformation
Notable Quotes: The proposed new powers for combatting misinformation and disinformation is inconsistent with a democracy which must allow dissenting views to be expressed & discussed freely.
The draft & proposed legislation requires transparency to the AUSTRALIAN PUBLIC & ELECTOR, is deceptively written & considered & should be WITHDRAWN without further amendment.
